channel.title: Windows Vista
channel.description: It was released today. What do you guys think about it?

@rob1601 wrote:

You are exagerating the concept of microsoft looking into your system. Yes there is some way of them viewing specific areas of your pc but no they will only do this if a ISP recieves complaints from a user. There is some network going on.

item.title: Windows Vista
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

I know it has more security flaws because it already came out in the news that it did and there is no way that Microsoft could give a shit to actually try to fix it. Which has been their attitude since the Windows OS came out.

All I know is, I’m sticking with XP until the next 2 or 3 Windows OS’s come out or I become wealthy enough to afford a mac or just get used to Linux. Haven’t made up my mind yet.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows Vista
item.dc:creator: @DeadBird DeadBird
item.description:
@DeadBird wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:35, topic:53424”][quote author=DeadBird link=topic=75337.msg845769#msg845769 date=1170236716]
Bill Gates plays Xbox 360. He is decent at PGR3.
[/quote]

Dumb noob :o everyone knows he’s playing his 720.[/quote]
Its actually a “361” - he has a Zephyr (black console, HDMI inputs, 120gig HD)[quote=“lothy, post:34, topic:53424”][quote author=DeadBird link=topic=75337.msg845980#msg845980 date=1170243360]

They can’t delete illegal content - But Vista can apparently check hardware against a database of approved hardware. Or at least I’d imagine it works like that; it’s not important anyway. What is important is that Vista can and will disable any hardware that allows playing of the illegal content. So if a DVD drive can play burnt movies like they can now, it would disable the DVD drive rendering it useless. That’s my understanding at least.

lol. My DVD drive on laptop works fine and I play bootleg DVDs on it from time to time.
[/quote]

http://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/~pgut001/pubs/vista_cost.html[/quote]
DVDs aren’t in HD, HD-DVD and Blu-ray movies are. Blame Sony & the HD-DVD assc. - they require the encryption on any display (High Definition Content Protection is built in to the disc players and in the PC drivers, no HDCP = no True HD) to play true HD.
The only TVs that are out and support HDCP are Sony Bravias which cost too much, and the monitors that support it (various brands) are $1000+.
I’m still waiting for facts.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows Vista
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“DeadBird, post:31, topic:53424”][quote author=lothy link=topic=75337.msg845959#msg845959 date=1170242636]
They can’t delete illegal content - But Vista can apparently check hardware against a database of approved hardware. Or at least I’d imagine it works like that; it’s not important anyway. What is important is that Vista can and will disable any hardware that allows playing of the illegal content. So if a DVD drive can play burnt movies like they can now, it would disable the DVD drive rendering it useless. That’s my understanding at least.
[/quote]
lol. My DVD drive on laptop works fine and I play bootleg DVDs on it from time to time.[/quote]

http://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/~pgut001/pubs/vista_cost.html[br][size=1]Posted on: 31 January 2007, 17:09:02[/size][hr][quote=“Zach1188, post:32, topic:53424”][quote author=lothy link=topic=75337.msg845959#msg845959 date=1170242636]
So if a DVD drive can play burnt movies like they can now, it would disable the DVD drive rendering it useless. That’s my understanding at least.
[/quote]
So, all current DVD drives would be disabled?

Lame.[/quote]
Yes. If a device doesn’t support encryption for “Premium content” (my understanding from what I read was any and every High Definition (HD) content), then it will be disabled.

Read the article I posted a link to for more specific information - They’ve looked into it a hell of a lot more then I have, but it’s fairly obvious - the goal of Vista is to more or less make piracy a thing of the past when it comes to high quality media of all sorts.

Oh, and another thing; funnily enough they can achieve all of this, and yet they probably still can’t protect end users from phishing etc. Amazing claps.

Read full topic
